Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Damage Defects and Diffusion of Noble Gases in Minerals: He in Zircon as a Model System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The noble gases (helium, neon, argon, krypton, xenon, and radon) play a central role in understanding a wide variety of Earth and planetary processes, from tracing the origins of meteorites, to the differentiation of Earth's mantle, to dating the timing and rates of geologic processes. However, while we can now measure noble gases in minerals very precisely, our understanding of how they are incorporated into, migrate through, and are lost from minerals is simplistic and likely wrong in important ways. This work will use a series of novel experiments to understand the behavior of one noble gas, helium, in one mineral, zircon, to build a general understanding of noble gas behavior in other systems.

The ability to measure distinct isotopes of helium in zircon specimens with differing amounts and types of crystal defects and crystallographic orientations (as well as the widespread utility of the radiogenic He radioisotopic dating system) make this an ideal model system for this work. The project will focus on radiogenic 4He, as well as 3He and 4He implanted or generated in situ in zircons with varying amounts of radiation damage from both heavy nuclide recoil and light ion or neutron damage, and will also examine the effects of damage defect annealing on He behavior. These experiments will distinguish between the effects of damage defects as traps, tortuosity enhancers, and fast-paths at various levels of pro- and retrograde accumulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The noble gases – helium, neon, argon, krypton, and xenon – are widely studied in the Earth sciences. They are chemically inert elements and are usually found in extremely low abundance in minerals because they do not fit into crystal structures. However, there is one important exception: noble gases can be produced by the radioactive decay of other elements. This makes the noble gases very useful as chronometers, with the amount of ingrown radiogenic noble gas recording the amount of time elapsed since it first began to accumulate in the mineral. This is the central idea behind geochronology, the methodology by which the formation ages of rocks are determined. In this methodology the radiogenic noble gas is assumed to accumulate as soon as the mineral crystallizes. For example, the accumulation of argon from potassium decay in the minerals making up a lava flow records when that lava flow cooled.

 

In the case of the smallest noble gas – helium – the situation is more interesting. When uranium and thorium decay in a mineral, they produce helium, but owing to its small size helium can migrate out of the mineral, and leak into the atmosphere. The helium migration rate is a very sensitive function of temperature: the higher the temperature, the higher the migration rate. In typical minerals, at temperatures above about 200oC, helium is lost as fast as it is produced: it does not accumulate. Because temperatures increase with depth in the crust, minerals more than a few kilometers below the surface are not accumulating He. Only as these rocks are transported to the surface, for example by erosion or by earthquakes, do they cool sufficiently to start accumulating helium. As a consequence, instead of recording the time elapsed since a rock formed, the accumulated helium records how long it has been since it cooled.  This methodology is called thermochronometry – a technique to determine the cooling history of rocks. This is a very useful piece of information.  For example, one key use of thermochronometry is to determine when and how mountain ranges form.

 

Quantitative interpretation of thermochronometric data requires a thorough and accurate understanding of the migration rate of noble gases in minerals. The mineral zircon, ZrSiO4, was studied as a model system by which to understand the details of how helium migration occurs in this mineral, and by inference, how other noble gases behave in minerals broadly defined. Of particular interest to this study was the response of helium migration to radiation damage. Radiation damage occurs when uranium and thorium decay, recoiling from their site of decay and leaving a substantial "hole" in the otherwise regular atomic arrangement in minerals. It was found that radiation damage plays a critical role in helium migration, with damage initially impeding the migration rate by trapping the helium in the damage holes. At greater degrees of damage, the ordered arrangement is sufficiently destroyed that the holes essentially interconnect, and helium migrates very readily. It was also found that natural healing of radiation damage in zircon can partially reverse the effect: as the mineral is returned to its ordered atomic arrangement, helium migration returns to normal. However, it was found that this return to an ordered state with normal helium migration rate does not occur once damage is too extreme. At extreme degrees of damage the zircon cannot knit itself back together.

These observations provide critical constraints for thermochronometry based on helium accumulation in zircon, and will facilitate future uses of this technique.These observations also contribute to the growing understanding of noble gas behavior in minerals, refining and expanding future uses of the noble gases as chronometers and tracers of geological processes.
